column1: === Climate ===
Its proximity to the Bay of Biscay gives Bilbao an oceanic climate (Cfb)
column2: with precipitation occurring throughout the year and without a well-defined dry summer. Precipitation is abundant
column3: and given the latitude and atmospheric dynamics
column4: rainy days represent 45% and cloudy days 40% of the annual total. The rainiest season is between October and April
column5: November being the wettest. Snow is not frequent in Bilbao
column6: although it is possible to see snow on the top of the surrounding mountains. Sleet is more frequent
column7: about 10 days per year
column8: mainly in the winter months. Bilbao is nearest to the subtropical boundary of all the Atlantic coastal cities in the country with an August daily mean of 20.9 °C (69.6 °F). There is also a drying trend in summer with only around 50 millimetres (2.0 in) of rainfall in July – but not dry enough to be considered Mediterranean.

column1: The proximity of the ocean also means that the two best defined seasons (summer and winter) remain mild
column2: with low intensity thermal oscillations. Average maximum temperatures vary between 25 and 26 °C (77.0 and 78.8 °F) in the summer months
column3: while the average minimum in winter is between 6 and 7 °C (42.8 and 44.6 °F).

column1: Extreme record observations in Bilbao are 42.0 °C (107.6 °F) maximum (on 26 July 1947) and  −8.6 °C (16.5 °F) minimum (on 3 February 1963). The maximum precipitation in a day was 225.6 mm (9 in) on 26 August 1983 when severe flooding was caused by the Nervión river.
